At a staff meeting that was on the record but at which taping was not permitted, journalists - including senior reporters and hosts - questioned what Knell's departure meant about the network's culture.
Knell's successor would be the seventh permanent or acting CEO in little more than seven years.

The company has tricky relationships with its member stations, who are at once its clients and its bosses on the NPR board, at a time the changes in the media landscape are dictating a more direct relationship between audiences and major media outlets.
And NPR has budget deficits to address as well.
But Knell said none of those challenges influenced his decision to depart.
Instead, in the interview, he sounded a bullish tone about the company's future.
This is a strong organization.
It has a strong balance sheet, it has an endowment; it's going to be around for many, many years.

This is a very strong organization.
